title: 10 Ways to Offer Support and Comfort Using Words

steps.title: Let them know that you recognize the magnitude of their pain.
steps.content: Let them know that you recognize the magnitude of their pain. Pick an appropriate time and situation and tell them you understand that they’re going through a difficult time. This can make the person feel more comfortable talking to you about it as well. [1] X Research source You don’t have to get specific if you don’t want to. You can say something like: “I know this must be a really difficult time for you and your family.” Or, say something like: “I know you must be feeling a lot of pain right now.”

steps.title: These words are a good starting point to console anyone.
steps.content: These words are a good starting point to console anyone. If you aren’t sure what the right words are to console someone, simply say “I’m sorry.” Add more details to expand on why you’re sorry if you’re comfortable doing so and if it’s appropriate. [2] X Research source For example, if your family member just had a miscarriage, you could say: “I’m really sorry you lost your baby.” Or, if your friend’s dad just died, you might say: “I’m really sorry to hear about your dad.”

steps.title: Show them you’re there for them by helping take their mind off the problem.
steps.content: Show them you’re there for them by helping take their mind off the problem. Ask the person to go out for a meal or to the movies. Or, invite them over to talk. Let them know there is a standing invitation any time they want to hang out and distract themselves from the difficult time they’re going through. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Psychological Association Leading scientific and professional organization of licensed psychologists Go to source For example, if your friend just lost a parent to suicide, say something like: “I’m really sorry that happened. I'm always here if you need some company. Do you want to go out to dinner this week?” Or, if a coworker is grieving over a break-up, tell them something like: “Hey, I’ve been there. If you want to get lunch one day to distract yourself, let me know!”

steps.title: This allows the person to express themselves and vent.
steps.content: This allows the person to express themselves and vent. Don’t assume you know what the person is feeling because of what they’re going through. Instead, ask them and let them tell you to help you understand their pain. Try saying something like: [4] X Research source [5] X Expert Source Connell Barrett Dating Coach Expert Interview. 24 September 2019. “Hey, I know this must be a difficult time. How are you feeling about things today?” “How does what happened make you feel?” "Why are you crying?" [6] X Expert Source Connell Barrett Dating Coach Expert Interview. 24 September 2019. "What has led you to feel this way?" [7] X Expert Source Connell Barrett Dating Coach Expert Interview. 24 September 2019.

steps.title: Show further understanding of what the person is going through.
steps.content: Show further understanding of what the person is going through. Listen to whatever the person is telling you about the difficult time they’re going through. [8] X Expert Source Connell Barrett Dating Coach Expert Interview. 24 September 2019. Try to make an honest reflection about the emotions they are experiencing. [9] X Research source For example, you might say something like: “I can tell you’re sad and confused about why this happened right now.” Or, you could say something like: “I understand why you’re feeling really hurt and angry about what just happened.” Empathy is a great way to console someone who's upset. [10] X Expert Source Connell Barrett Dating Coach Expert Interview. 24 September 2019. Reader Poll: We asked 1979 wikiHow readers, and 61% of them agreed that the best way to comfort someone when they confide in you about personal issues is to show empathy and offer support . [Take Poll]

steps.title: People often bottle up feelings of sadness because they’re ashamed to cry.
steps.content: People often bottle up feelings of sadness because they’re ashamed to cry. Tell the person who’s going through a hard time that it’s totally fine for them to cry in front of you if they need to. Letting it all out can really help someone through the healing process. [11] X Research source For example, if your friend is putting on a tough face after his wife left him, but you know he’s hurting, say: “Man, if you need to cry, go ahead. I know you’re hurting right now.” Or, if your friend is sad because her dog just died, say: “I’m here if you need a shoulder to cry on. You don’t have to hold back any tears in front of me.”

steps.title: These 3 words can really console a close friend or family member.
steps.content: These 3 words can really console a close friend or family member. When you see someone you really care about going through a hard time, make an extra effort to simply say “I love you.” They need as much love as they can get right now. [12] X Research source For example, if your brother is sad because his dog just died, say: “Hey bro, I just wanted you to know that I love you.” Or, if your best friend just lost a parent and just got done telling you about it on the phone, say: “I love you, man.” before you get off the phone.

steps.title: It’s okay to be saddened by their loss or to not know what to say.
steps.content: It’s okay to be saddened by their loss or to not know what to say. If you don’t know how to console someone, tell them that, but make it clear that you care. Or, if you feel affected by someone else’s loss and grief, tell them how you feel to show that you understand. [13] X Research source For example, you might say: “Wow, I’m so sorry about your dad’s passing. We had a lot of good times with him growing up, didn’t we? That makes me really sad, too.” Or, you could say: “Hey, I don’t really know what to say right now, and my words probably won’t make it hurt any less, but I just want you to know I care and I’m here for you.”

steps.title: People usually aren't looking for advice when they’re sad or upset.
steps.content: People usually aren't looking for advice when they’re sad or upset. Avoid giving the person advice about what they should or shouldn’t do during this difficult time. Instead, focus on making sure they know you’re they’re for them and acknowledging that they’re passing through a really difficult moment. [14] X Research source For example, if someone is sad because their cat just ran away and disappeared, don’t tell them they should have checked their windows before they went out. Instead, say something like, “I’m really sorry that happened. Can I help you look for your cat?” Or, if someone is upset because they got fired from their job, don’t say, “You should go start applying for new jobs right now.” Instead, say something like: “That really sucks, I’m sorry. Let me know if there’s anything I can do to help when you start job hunting.”

steps.title: Comments you make with good intentions might upset the person more.
steps.content: Comments you make with good intentions might upset the person more. Don’t tell someone who just lost a loved one that they are in a better place or that it was God’s will, for instance. Avoid using cliches like “It wasn’t meant to be,” to justify things like breakups or job losses. [15] X Research source For example, if your friend’s dad just passed away, don’t say, “At least he’s no longer suffering.” Instead, say, “I’m really sorry. I know how hard this moment is for you.” Or, if your girlfriend just lost her job, don’t say, “It probably wasn’t a good fit, anyways.” Instead, say, “I know you’re feeling a bit lost right now, but I’m here to help you however I can.”
